sect1.title: Querying SQL
sect1.para: This chapter describes the query type generation and querying functionality of the SQL module.

sect2.title: Maven integration
sect2.para: Add the following dependencies to your Maven project:
sect2.programlisting:
<dependency> <groupId>io.github.openfeign.querydsl</groupId> <artifactId>querydsl-sql</artifactId> <version>${querydsl.version}</version> </dependency>
<dependency> <groupId>io.github.openfeign.querydsl</groupId> <artifactId>querydsl-sql-codegen</artifactId> <version>${querydsl.version}</version> <scope>provided</scope> </dependency>
sect2.para: The querydsl-sql-codegen dependency can be skipped, if code generation happens via Maven.

sect2.title: Code generation via Maven
sect2.para: This functionality should be primarily used via the Maven plugin. Here is an example:
sect2.programlisting: <project> <build> <plugins> ... <plugin> <groupId>io.github.openfeign.querydsl</groupId> <artifactId>querydsl-maven-plugin</artifactId> <version>${querydsl.version}</version> <executions> <execution> <goals> <goal>export</goal> </goals> </execution> </executions> <configuration> <jdbcDriver>org.apache.derby.jdbc.EmbeddedDriver</jdbcDriver> <jdbcUrl>jdbc:derby:target/demoDB;create=true</jdbcUrl> <packageName>com.myproject.domain</packageName> <targetFolder>${project.basedir}/target/generated-sources/java</targetFolder> </configuration> <dependencies> <dependency> <groupId>org.apache.derby</groupId> <artifactId>derby</artifactId> <version>${derby.version}</version> </dependency> </dependencies> </plugin> ... </plugins> </build> </project>
sect2.para: Use the goal test-export to treat the target folder as a test source folder for use with test code.

sect2.programlisting: <customTypes> <customType>com.querydsl.sql.types.InputStreamType</customType> </customTypes>

sect2.programlisting:

They can be customized for specific total/decimal digits combinations like this:
sect2.programlisting: <numericMappings> <numericMapping> <total>1</total> <decimal>0</decimal> <javaType>java.lang.Byte</javaType> </numericMapping> </numericMappings>
sect2.para: Imports can be used to add cross-schema foreign keys support.
Schemas, tables and columns can also be renamed using the plugin. Here are some examples:
Renaming a schema:
sect2.programlisting: <renameMappings> <renameMapping> <fromSchema>PROD</fromSchema> <toSchema>TEST</toSchema> </renameMapping> </renameMappings>
sect2.para: Renaming a table:
sect2.programlisting: <renameMappings> <renameMapping> <fromSchema>PROD</fromSchema> <fromTable>CUSTOMER</fromTable> <toTable>CSTMR</toTable> </renameMapping> </renameMappings>
sect2.para: Renaming a column:
sect2.programlisting: <renameMappings> <renameMapping> <fromSchema>PROD</fromSchema> <fromTable>CUSTOMER</fromTable> <fromColumn>ID</fromColumn> <toColumn>IDX</toTable> </renameMapping> </renameMappings>
sect2.para: Note: fromSchema can be omitted when renaming tables and columns.
Compared to APT based code generation certain functionality is not available such as QueryDelegate annotation handling.

sect2.title: Code generation via ANT
sect2.para: The ANT task com.querydsl.sql.codegen.ant.AntMetaDataExporter of the querydsl-sql module provides the same functionality as an ANT task. The configuration parameters of the task are the same as for the Maven plugin, except for the composite types.
The composite types are used without the wrapper element like in this example.
sect2.programlisting:
<project name="testproject" default="codegen" basedir=".">
<taskdef name="codegen" classname="com.querydsl.sql.codegen.ant.AntMetaDataExporter"/>
<target name="codegen"> <codegen jdbcDriver="org.h2.Driver" jdbcUser="sa" jdbcUrl="jdbc:h2:/dbs/db1" packageName="test" targetFolder="target/generated-sources/java"> <renameMapping fromSchema="PUBLIC" toSchema="PUB"/> </codegen> </target> </project>

sect2.title: Creating the query types
sect2.para: To get started export your schema into Querydsl query types like this:
This declares that the database schema is to be mirrored into the com.myproject.domain package in the target/generated-sources/java folder.

The generated types have the table name transformed to mixed case as the class name and a similar mixed case transformation applied to the columns which are available as property paths in the query type.
In addition to this primary key and foreign key constraints are provided as fields which can be used for compact join declarations.

sect2.title: Configuration
sect2.para: The configuration is done via the com.querydsl.sql.Configuration class which takes the Querydsl SQL dialect as an argument. For H2 you would create it like this
sect2.programlisting: SQLTemplates templates = new H2Templates(); Configuration configuration = new Configuration(templates);
sect2.para: Querydsl uses SQL dialects to customize the SQL serialization needed for different relational databases. The available dialects are:
For customized SQLTemplates instances you can use the builder pattern like this
sect2.programlisting: H2Templates.builder() .printSchema() // to include the schema in the output .quote() // to quote names .newLineToSingleSpace() // to replace new lines with single space in the output .escape(ch) // to set the escape char .build(); // to get the customized SQLTemplates instance
sect2.para: The methods of the Configuration class can be used to enable direct serialization of literals via setUseLiterals(true), override schema and tables and register custom types. For full details look at the javadocs of Configuration.

sect2.title: Querying
sect2.para: For the following examples we will be using the SQLQueryFactory class for query creation. Using it results in more concise code compared to constructor based query creation.
sect2.programlisting: SQLQueryFactory queryFactory = new SQLQueryFactory(configuration, dataSource);
sect2.para: Querying with Querydsl SQL is as simple as this:
which is transformed into the following sql query, assuming that the related table name is customer and the columns first_name and last_name:
sect2.programlisting: SELECT c.last_name FROM customer c WHERE c.first_name = 'Bob'

sect2.title: General usage
sect2.para: Use the the cascading methods of the SQLQuery class like this
select: Set the projection of the query. (Not necessary if created via query factory)
from: Add the query sources here.
innerJoin, join, leftJoin, rightJoin, fullJoin, on: Add join elements using these constructs. For the join methods the first argument is the join source and the second the target (alias).
where: Add query filters, either in varargs form separated via commas or cascaded via the and-operator.
groupBy: Add group by arguments in varargs form.
having: Add having filter of the "group by" grouping as an varags array of Predicate expressions.
orderBy: Add ordering of the result as an varargs array of order expressions. Use asc() and desc() on numeric, string and other comparable expression to access the OrderSpecifier instances.
limit, offset, restrict: Set the paging of the result. Limit for max results, offset for skipping rows and restrict for defining both in one call.

sect2.title: Joins
sect2.para: Joins are constructed using the following syntax:
and for a left join:
sect2.programlisting: queryFactory.select(customer.firstName, customer.lastName, company.name) .from(customer) .leftJoin(customer.company, company) .fetch();
sect2.para: Alternatively the join condition can also be written out:
sect2.programlisting: queryFactory.select(customer.firstName, customer.lastName, company.name) .from(customer) .leftJoin(company).on(customer.company.eq(company)) .fetch();

sect2.title: Ordering
sect2.para: The syntax for declaring ordering is
sect2.programlisting: queryFactory.select(customer.firstName, customer.lastName) .from(customer) .orderBy(customer.lastName.asc(), customer.firstName.asc()) .fetch();
sect2.para: which is equivalent to the following native SQL
sect2.programlisting: SELECT c.first_name, c.last_name FROM customer c ORDER BY c.last_name ASC, c.first_name ASC

sect2.title: Grouping
sect2.para: Grouping can be done in the following form
sect2.programlisting: queryFactory.select(customer.lastName) .from(customer) .groupBy(customer.lastName) .fetch();
sect2.para: which is equivalent to the following native SQL
sect2.programlisting: SELECT c.last_name FROM customer c GROUP BY c.last_name

sect2.title: Using Subqueries
sect2.para: To create a subquery you can use one of the factory methods of SQLExpressions and add the query parameters via from, where etc.
sect2.programlisting: QCustomer customer = QCustomer.customer; QCustomer customer2 = new QCustomer("customer2"); queryFactory.select(customer.all()) .from(customer) .where(customer.status.eq( SQLExpressions.select(customer2.status.max()).from(customer2))) .fetch()

sect2.title: Selecting literals
sect2.para: To select literals you need to create constant instances for them like this:
sect2.programlisting: queryFactory.select(Expressions.constant(1), Expressions.constant("abc"));
sect2.para: The class com.querydsl.core.types.dsl.Expressions offers also other useful static methods for projections, operation and template creation.

sect2.title: Query extension support
sect2.para: Custom query extensions to support engine specific syntax can be created by subclassing AbstractSQLQuery and adding flagging methods like in the given MySQLQuery example:
The flags are custom SQL snippets that can be inserted at specific points in the serialization. The supported positions are the enums of the com.querydsl.core.QueryFlag.Position enum class.

sect2.title: Window functions
sect2.para: Window functions are supported in Querydsl via the methods in the SQLExpressions class.
Usage example:
sect2.programlisting: queryFactory.select(SQLExpressions.rowNumber() .over() .partitionBy(employee.name) .orderBy(employee.id)) .from(employee)

sect2.title: Common table expressions
sect2.para: Common table expressions are supported in Querydsl SQL via two syntax variants
sect2.programlisting: QEmployee employee = QEmployee.employee; queryFactory.with(employee, SQLExpressions.select(employee.all) .from(employee) .where(employee.name.startsWith("A"))) .from(...)
sect2.para: And using a column listing
sect2.programlisting: QEmployee employee = QEmployee.employee; queryFactory.with(employee, employee.id, employee.name) .as(SQLExpressions.select(employee.id, employee.name) .from(employee) .where(employee.name.startsWith("A"))) .from(...)
sect2.para: If the columns of the common table expression are a subset of an existing table or view it is advisable to use a generated path type for it, e.g. QEmployee in this case, but if the columns don't fit any existing table PathBuilder can be used instead.

sect2.title: Extracting the SQL query and bindings
sect2.para: The SQL query and bindings can be extracted via the getSQL method:
sect2.programlisting: SQLBindings bindings = query.getSQL(); System.out.println(bindings.getSQL());
sect2.para: If you need also all literals in the SQL string you can enable literal serialization on the query or configuration level via setUseLiterals(true).

sect2.title: Custom types
sect2.para: Querydsl SQL provides the possibility to declare custom type mappings for ResultSet/Statement interaction. The custom type mappings can be declared in com.querydsl.sql.Configuration instances, which are supplied as constructor arguments to the actual queries:
And for a table column
To customize a numeric mapping you can use the registerNumeric method like this
sect2.programlisting: configuration.registerNumeric(5,2,Float.class);
sect2.para: This will map the Float type to the NUMERIC(5,2) type.

sect2.title: Listening to queries and clauses
sect2.para: SQLListener is a listener interface that can be used to listen to queries and DML clause. SQLListener instances can be registered either on the configuration and on the query/clause level via the addListener method.
Use cases for listeners are data synchronization, logging, caching and validation.
